WINS BARNSTORMERS
POSTER CONTEST
Miss Miriam Best was announced yesterday as the
winner of the poster contest
sponsored by the Barnstormer
Club. Miss Best's was judged
best of the 38 posters entered
by various art students. The
winner was awarded eight
orchestra seats for "The
Black Flamingo."
S. Jesse Robinson and the
rest of the publicity staff have
been working hard to get the
Baltimore public interested in
the work of the Club. Large
night-illuminated billboards on
nine of Baltimore's important
streets advertise the coming
production.
It has been announced that
Dr. and Mrs. Ames and Dr.
and Mrs. Berry will occupy a
box at the Lyric on Saturday
night, December 6.

Jay Harriers Swamp
Gettysburg College
To Close Season With Terps Next
Wednesday

In a meet with Gettysburg College last Wednesday the Johns
Hopkins cross-country team defeated their rivals by the perfect
score of 15-40.
The first six men to cross the
finish line, Packard, Sneeringer,
Jung, Hancock, Glass and Cornman, were of the Jay contingent.
The Hopkins team will run its
final and most imfportant meet of
the season on Wednesday with the
University of Maryland.

Athletic Council Reorganized
Under New Plan; Letter
Men to be Elected to
Board
At the first meeting of the Athletic Association held on Monday,
November 17, 1930-1931 officers
were elected: John Heinzerling,
president; Edwin Lockard, secretary-treasurer. It was decided to
petition the Athletic Council to
recognize swimming as a minor
sport at the university. Robert
Kyle and Edwin Lockard were appointed to attend the next meeting
of the council for this purpose.
Paid Way Last Year

Last year swimming had the
status of an informal sport at Hopkins. No official recognition was
given it, and it was only a club. It
received no financial aid from the
college, and had to operate under
difficulties, financing its own meets,
paying for the pool in which it
practiced out of the pockets of the
individuals.
This year, however, in response
to popular pressure, the Athletic
Association has decided to petition
the Athletic Council for recognition
for the swimming team. If this
recognition is granted, the swimming team will be able to receive
financial support from the Student
Activities Council.

ALLIANCE PLAYERS TO
ENTERTAIN COSMOPOLITANS TOMORROW
There will be a meeting of
the Cosmopolitan Club tomorrow evening in Levering Hall.
A very elaborate program has
been planned for this meeting,
says Mr. Teper, president of
the club. The Alliance Players, one of the Baltimore Little Theatre groups, will present two one-act comedies:
"Hot Lemonade" and "The
First Dress Suit". Dancing
will follow the presentation of
the plays. All students interested in the work of the Cosmopolitan Club are invited to
attend this meeting.

Bureau of Appointments
Presents Annual Report
In the annual report of the bureau of appointments, which is part
of the president's report; R. N.
Dempster, registrar of the university and director of the bureau,
states that last year 32 students
were placed in permanent business
positions. Eight students were
given positions as teachers, while
513 others were placed in part time
or summer employment.
The representatives of many important concerns came to Hopkins
last year in order to speak to the
members of the senior class.
It was also reported that a total
of $3,575 was given out as loans.
The faculty of philosophy students
received six loans totaling $1,500.
The students in the Arts and Science department received three
loans totaling $900. Three loans
totaling $700 were given to students in the Engineering department, while a Medical Schol student received a loan of $300, and a
college for teachers one of $175.,

Studies of judicial administration in the states of Ohio, Maryland and New York are being made
by the Institute of Law, of the
Johns Hopkins University, it was
learned today from a letter written by Dr. Joseph S. Ames, the
Hopkins president, to financial supporters of the institute's projects.
Tells Supporters of Progress

In his letter, Dr. Ames said: "Because of your interest in the program of the Institute of Law at
this university and the generous
support you have given toward its
development, I know you will be
interested in a statement of the
present activities of the Institute.
"In progress at this time are the
following studies, all of which relate to the improvement of the administration of justice."
Conducting Ohio Law Study

As cited by Dr. Ames, the Institute is conducting the Ohio judicial
study, which began January 1,
1930, at the invitation of the Ohio
Judicial Council. The program, it
is said, includes a comprehensive
analysis of all the litigation of the
state, and special inquiries by faculty members of leading Ohio universities in co-operation with the
faculty of the Institute of Law at
Homewood.
At the request of Governor Albert C. Ritchie, the Institute has
undertaken a study of Maryland's
judiciary problems. In this state,
the Maryland Judicial Council and
Chief Judge Carroll T. Bond, of
the Maryland State Court of Appeals, is co-operating with the Hopkins legal investigators. Having
been instituted on July 1, 1930, the
work has been advanced to the
study of litigation in the lower
courts.

Burnished mirror-bright, etched in an

in the projector microscope in the metallography room at Crane laboratories.
To the layman, the texture disclosed is
surprising as the filigree design of magnified snowflakes. Sometimes it is like a
relief map of mountain ranges,sometimes
like finely veined marble,sometimes like
cumulous clouds.
But to the scientist in metals who judges
it with a connoisseur's eye, the surface
tells a far wider story. It discloses coarse
uneven or beautiful fine grains, tells of
disproportions and proportions of constituents in the alloy, speaks volumes
concerning malleability, ductility, hardness...gives a key to action ofthe metal
in service, all based upon knowledge of
the product.
Careful metallographic records of all
metals used in Crane valves and fittings,
painstaking microscopic examination of
all new metals offered for possible use,
are a part of the check and double check
and triple check which is routine in Crane
research and manufacturing.
The full story of Crane application of
chemistry and science to metals is told in
afascinating book,"Pioneering in Science."

Officers Nominated For Coming Year;
Elections Tuesday

A supper conference, sponsored
by the Y. M. C. A. was held last
Tuesday at 6 P. M. in Levering
Hall, and was attended by 15 freshmen. The purpose of the meeting
was to acquaint the Frosh with the
significance of the Freshman Y. M.
C. A. Cabinet, and to nominate the
officers of that body for the coming year.
The following men were nominated for office: for president and
vice-president, Rife, McConnell and
Weeks; for secretary, Bennett,
Roll, DeWolff, Davis; for treasurer, Scott, Scharr and Hill.
Next Tuesday the nominations
will be reopened and the officers
elected.
Carroll Hughes presided at the
meeting and requested Edwin Lockard, last year's president of the "Y"
to express his impressions of the
organization. Lockard emphatically
recommended it as a school for the
development of ideas and ideals.
John Mount, present president of
the "Y", defined Y. M. C. A. work
as possessing an "indescribable
something" which holds a person,
reworking and broadaning his
opinions. He also cited examples
from his personal experiences.
Mr. Schaal, carrying further the
thread of Lockard's and Mount's
discourses, explained that the distinction between the Y. M. C. A.
Cabinet and the "Y" itself, is that
the former is the organization of
the working members while the latter includes all those who have declared themselves as advocating the
